results.title: Lori Belilove and company: the art of Isadora Duncan
results.brief_description: Compilation of excerpts of eight dances performed by Lori Belilove & Company celebrating the legacy of Isadora Duncan. Combines improvised outdoor footage of company in performance around the world with additional footage from the films “Isadora Duncan: movement of the soul” and “Oneiro: in the shadow of Isadora” (also held in collection). Choreography by Lori Belilove after dances by Isadora Duncan.

results.title: Lords of the wild
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger and Grainger Television Australia
results.brief_description: This is a superb documentary featuring every species of bear around the world, and their fight for survival. Contains images which seemingly show that bears, as a species, are thriving; the truth is somewhat less attractive. The polar bear is the only species surviving in sufficient numbers in the wild to make it relatively safe, some of their darker cousins are staring extinction right in the face.

results.title: Lords of the forest
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Barnes, Alan Bateman and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Journey into Thailand”.
Keith Adam presents this program which explores the teak forests of Thailand, one of the last places in the world where elephants are still used commercially. It shows an elephant festival, a tug-of-war between an elephant and 150 soldiers and a soccer game played by elephants.

results.title: Lord Siva danced
results.creator_credit: Sarah Erulkar and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: An introduction to Indian Cclassical dancing, showing four types of dance which have been part of Indian culture for centuries. Indian classical dancing is a vital part of Indian mythology and religion, tracing its origins to religious rituals and performed as a form of worship. Indian dancing has its own grammar, the language of the dance having been developed to a point where every movement of the dancer’s body is eloquently expressive. As in European ballet, dancers begin their training as children, and dancing becomes their life. The first dancer introduced in this film is Ram Gopal, one of the most famous Indian dancers. The dance he performs illustrates the manner in which various highly stylised movements, known as dance phrases, express what might be put into words to form a phrase; it is from such a movement that the film takes it name; the dance performed by Ram Gopal is in the tradition of south-eastern India. The second dance, performed by Shevanti, is typical of the dances of the north-east of India. It doesn’t tell a story, as Gopal’s dance does, but simply invokes and expresses a mood. The third dance by Rajeshwar is an example of the Kathakali or dance-drama of southern India and tells the story of bees and the lotus flower, entirely in terms of movement of his face and hands. All these dances form part of Hindu culture. The fourth dance by Chandupanikar has been preserved under Muslim influence in the north-west of India. The final dance is created from the movements of traditional classical dancing. Photographed by Keki Mistri. Commentary by Sarah Erulkar.

results.title: Lord Rutherford
results.brief_description: An historic film of Lord Rutherford, pioneer in atomic physics and winner of 1930 Faraday Medal. New Zealand born Lord Rutherford discusses the structure of atoms, means of breaking up the stable elements, transmutation experiments, the rise in new departments of chemical knowledge and the ultimate structure of matter.

results.title: Lord of the bush (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Lord Alistair McAlpine, entrepreneur and Treasurer of Margaret Thatcher’s Conservative Party is opening Broome for Tourism. Examines the issues that have been raised including Aboriginal land rights and the conflict between tourist developments and conservation. Interviews colourful Broome identities and their reactions to the changes. ** PLEASE CONSULT WITH SENIOR MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY, AS PERSONS WHO APPEAR

results.title: Lord Howe Island: jewel of the Pacific
results.brief_description: The World around us highlights the natural drama of a year in the life of Lord Howe Island, from the nesting seabirds to the world’s most southern coral reef. The history of the island, the tragedy of its exploitation and the modern-day struggle to preserve the unique values are presented.

results.title: Loose ends
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The Long Search”.
In this concluding episode Ronald Eyre attempts to answer questions such as “Is religion about theology?”, “Is God dead?”, “Do all religions say the same thing?” In a program filled with such questions and many more personal ones besides, he revisits some of the crucial moments in his search including his visits to Romania, the Buddhist monks and the taoist funeral, concluding that in order to find true religion, one first has to find oneself.

results.title: Loops to learn by
results.creator_credit: Rex Tasker, Dorothy Courtois, Robert Verrall and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: One of the most practical and productive of innovations in educational visual aids was the 8mm single-concept film loop contained in a cassette inserted into a projector simple enough for a young child to operate. This film tells how a series of such loops for people with learning disabilities were developed with the advice of psychologists, and shows situations in which they can be usefully employed.

results.title: Loops = Boucles
results.brief_description: An experimental film in which percussive rhythm is integrated with simple geometric abstractions, both visuals and sound being created by the artist, Norman McLaren. Visuals and sounds are drawn by hand directly on raw film with ordinary pen and ink. Neither camera nor sound recording equipment has been used in the making of this film.
